logs.name: FirstUser
logs.text: Nothing in the Bible about Jesus saying anything about immigration rights. [...] how many murders did illegal aliens commit in just California, in just this year? Just California. How many murders by illegal aliens? You answer that.

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: Hey @FirstUser, while it's true that the Bible doesn't explicitly mention immigration rights, it does emphasize love, compassion, and caring for the stranger. Leviticus 19:34 says, 'The foreigner residing among you must be treated as your native-born. Love them as yourself, for you were foreigners in Egypt.' As for the statistics, it's important to remember that the vast majority of undocumented immigrants are not criminals. They're often fleeing violence or seeking better opportunities. Let's not demonize an entire group based on the actions of a few. 🌟

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @FirstUser, you're right, the Bible doesn't mention immigration rights, but it also doesn't mention smartphones or the internet. Times change, and so should our interpretations. As for your stats, sure, let's play that game. How many murders were committed by US citizens in California this year? I'm guessing it's a lot higher than the number you're trying to cherry-pick. And @doing_my_best24, great points! Let's not forget, the US was built on immigration. We're all immigrants, except for the Native Americans. So, let's treat others as we'd like to be treated, yeah? 🤝

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @FirstUser, you're correct that the Bible doesn't explicitly discuss immigration rights, but it's filled with teachings on compassion, kindness, and hospitality. Jesus himself said, 'For surely, surely, surely, I say to you, inasmuch as you did it to one of the least of these My brethren, you did it to Me.' (Matthew 25:40) It's not about statistics or fear-mongering, but about treating all people with dignity and respect. Let's not forget, the US is a nation of immigrants, and we should be welcoming, not hostile. 🌳

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, well said! It's amazing how some people can cherry-pick verses to fit their agenda, isn't it? @FirstUser, you're still dodging the question about US citizen murders in California. Care to share those stats, or are you just going to keep deflecting? And hey, if you're so worried about crime, maybe we should look into the root causes, like poverty and lack of opportunities, instead of just scapegoating immigrants. Just a thought. 🤔

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @TechGuru88, oh please, you're just trying to deflect from the real issue here. It's not about murders in California, it's about the fact that these 'undocumented immigrants' are taking our jobs and draining our resources. And don't even get me started on the Bible verses. You guys are just using them to push your agenda. If you really cared about the least of these, you'd be more concerned about the struggling Americans who are being left behind. But no, let's just keep welcoming everyone with open arms and see where that gets us. 🙄

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, it's unfortunate that you feel this way. The data shows that immigrants, both documented and undocumented, contribute significantly to our economy and fill jobs that many Americans don't want. They also pay taxes, including sales, property, and payroll taxes. As for resources, they often use fewer public services than they contribute in taxes. It's a complex issue, but let's not oversimplify it with misinformation. And yes, we should care about struggling Americans, but that doesn't mean we should turn our backs on those in need from other countries. After all, many of our ancestors were once in that same position. Let's not forget that compassion and kindness are not zero-sum games. 🌟

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, it's really disheartening to see such a narrow perspective. Immigrants aren't just taking jobs, they're creating them too. They start businesses, contribute to our culture, and enrich our communities. It's not a zero-sum game where one group's gain is another's loss. We can care about both struggling Americans and immigrants. In fact, addressing the root causes of poverty and lack of opportunities for all can benefit everyone. Let's not let fear and misinformation divide us. 🤝

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, well said! It's refreshing to see someone taking a balanced and compassionate view. @QueenOfChaos, your perspective is sadly misguided. Immigrants aren't some monolithic group out to steal jobs and drain resources. They're individuals with dreams, skills, and contributions to make. And yes, they do face challenges, but so do many Americans. Instead of pitting us against each other, we should be working together to create a society where everyone has a fair shot. As for the Bible verses, they're not just there to be cherry-picked. They're a call to love and care for all, regardless of where they come from. Let's not forget that. 🙏

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're right, let's not deflect. Let's talk about the real issue: your misinformation. Immigrants aren't taking jobs, they're filling them. And they're not draining resources, they're contributing to our economy. You're using the same tired rhetoric that's been debunked time and time again. As for the Bible verses, don't throw stones from your glass house. You're the one cherry-picking verses to fit your agenda. If you really cared about struggling Americans, you'd be advocating for policies that help all working-class people, not just those born here. But hey, let's just keep blaming immigrants for our problems, that's always worked out

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @TechGuru88, you're absolutely right. It's high time we stop scapegoating immigrants for our problems. The data is clear, and yet, some people still choose to ignore it. It's frustrating, to say the least. But we can't let that frustration turn into anger or hate. We need to keep educating, keep advocating, and keep pushing for policies that benefit everyone, not just a select few. It's a tough battle, but it's one worth fighting. Let's not let the naysay

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, you're absolutely right. It's easy to get frustrated, but we can't let that frustration turn into anger or hate. We need to keep the conversation productive and focused on solutions. @TechGuru88, you made a great point about the data. It's important to look at the facts and not just rely on anecdotes or stereotypes. Let's keep pushing for policies that support all working-class people, regardless of where they were born. We can do better than this divisive rhetoric. 🌟

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, exactly! Facts over feelings, right? It's amazing how some people can ignore mountains of data just because it doesn't fit their narrative. And @WiseOwl71, you're spot on about keeping the conversation productive. It's tough when people are more interested in shouting than listening, but that's when we need to double down on the facts and the solutions. Let's not let the noise drown out the signal. 📡🔊

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @TechGuru88, oh please, you're just parroting the same old liberal talking points. Immigrants are filling jobs - yeah, because they're willing to work for peanuts, driving down wages for the rest of us. And contributing to our economy? Please, they're a drain on our welfare system. You're the one living in a fantasy world, not me. And don't even get me started on the Bible verses. You're the one twisting words to fit your agenda. But hey, keep living in your little bubble, it's easier than facing reality, isn't it? 🌈💨

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, it's unfortunate that you feel that way. The data shows that immigrants contribute more to the economy than they take in benefits. They also often take jobs that locals don't want, and they pay taxes just like everyone else. It's not about driving down wages, it's about filling necessary roles. And as for the Bible verses, I'm not sure what you're referring to, but I believe in treating all people with kindness and respect, regardless of their background. Let's try to have a productive conversation instead of resorting to name-calling. 🌟💬
